texts.orig: Updates
texts.text: Updates

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First and foremost, I love how CoreOS does updates. I encourage you to  read the docs  on this topic, but here's a short explanation:
texts.text: First and foremost, I love how CoreOS does updates. I encourage you to  read the docs  on this topic, but here's a short explanation:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Updates are automatically retrieved and they're loaded into a slot.
texts.text: Updates are automatically retrieved and they're loaded into a slot.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your system reboots into the new update but your original OS tree remains in place.
texts.text: Your system reboots into the new update but your original OS tree remains in place.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Did the update boot? Awesome. You're good to go.
texts.text: Did the update boot? Awesome. You're good to go.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Did something break? The system reverts back to the known good tree.
texts.text: Did something break? The system reverts back to the known good tree.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In this way, it's a lot like your smartphone.
texts.text: In this way, it's a lot like your smartphone.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You have full control over when a node looks for an update and how often it checks for them. Check out the  Zincati docs  for tons of controls over updates and reboots.
texts.text: You have full control over when a node looks for an update and how often it checks for them. Check out the  Zincati docs  for tons of controls over updates and reboots.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some of mine are timed so well that I set maintenance windows with my monitoring provider when I know an update might take place. The updates come through, monitoring shuts off, the node reboots, and monitoring comes back. The nodes almost always come back before the monitoring even alerts me.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It also removes the reminders I would set for myself to update packages and run reboots. I know that my CoreOS nodes will do this automatically, so I don't need to think about it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Also, updates are rarely ever impactful to my workloads since all of them are running inside containers. My containers come right back up as soon as the node finishes its reboot.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Pets and cattle
texts.text: Pets and cattle

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: CoreOS works well for systems that I only need online for a short time. These might be situations where I need to test a few containers and throw it away. There's no OS to mess with and no updates to worry about.
texts.text: CoreOS works well for systems that I only need online for a short time. These might be situations where I need to test a few containers and throw it away. There's no OS to mess with and no updates to worry about.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It also works well for systems that I keep online for a long time. I have a few physical systems at home that run CoreOS and they've been extremely stable. I also have cloud instances on Hetzner, VULTR, and Digital Ocean that have run CoreOS for months without issues.
